annotations:
[('Cradle me, I’ll cradle you', [['The previous track ‘First Love’ talks about the fantasies and hopes for a relationship with the person’s love interest, progressing eventually to a lore completion with ‘Toothpaste Kisses’, in this song the couple have finally settled and are in a relationship.

Though, we can’t ignore the fact that they are both new to dating, (that’s why ‘First Love’) the person expresses how though he or she is too unsure to make the first move, they can assure to his or her lover that whatever cheesy action is in mind it will be reciprocal.']]), ('I’ll be yours and you’ll be...', [['The way the artist states that he will be hers shows how dedicated he is to her. However, he doesn’t finish saying what he’ll be to her; ‘And you’ll be [blank]’. This could suggest that the love he has for her isn’t mutual.']]), ('Doin’ things that lovers do
 What else to do?', [['They are imitating being in love by ‘doing the things that lovers do’. They don’t know what else to do with themselves, and the song is left on an ominous and slightly hopeless note.']]), ('And with heart shaped bruises', [['In-keeping with the theme of love with possibly some darker undertones, heart shaped bruises is rather ambiguous.
It could be in reference to hickeys that the couple have left on each other; but there is a choice made in not calling them ‘love bites’, a more romantic way to describe them.
Calling them bruises makes it sound a little darker. Perhaps a metaphor for them emotionally hurting each other, but framing it like it’s love. Maybe they are even physically hurting each other.']]), ('So with toothpaste kisses and lines', [['He illustrates their love through the image of toothpaste, since brushing your teeth is typically the last thing you do before you go to bed. “Toothpaste kisses” in particular is likely just kisses shared in bed together, happy and ready to fall asleep.']]), ('Put the stars in our eyes', [['Having stars in one’s eyes is an idiomatic phrase for being enchanted romantically, as the narrator no doubt is by their partner.

However, Weeks may be intending a double entendre here as being ‘starry-eyed’ expresses having naively optimistic outlooks (on the relationship, in this case).

It seems the narrator is very much in love with their partner, however knows it is not mutual and is therefore trying to console this by ‘putting stars in their eyes’: holding hope for the couple where there is very little to go on.']]), ('Pulling shapes just for your eyes', [['He’s attempting to impress her with his dancing prowess (or at least hypothetically).']]), ('Stay with me, I’ll stay with you', [['I feel as if the singer is saying how their love life is undetermined. he asks her to stay with him, as he will dedicate himself to her, but he is afraid that she will leave him.

earlier in this song, the incompletion of “I’ll be yours, and you’ll be” is another reasoning for the way he feels about her, as he does not tell us if she desires him the same way he desires her.']])]

I realised before that sometimes these feelings that I thought that I had for a person could have been romanticising the past just because I’m lonely now, and sometimes you have to ask yourself, ‘What do you really feel?’ Or sometimes you kind of run away to this illusion, to something that isn’t real, maybe to protect yourself from the present and from something that could be real. I feel like you just have to kind of ask yourself and evaluate, ‘Do I really really still have feelings for this person?’ And if you really, really do, I feel like it’s important to say it because life is too short.']])]
